stat-node-1.title: Identifying Categorical vs Numerical Data
learningFocus: Distinguish between categorical (labels/names) and numerical (measurements/counts) data
Recognize that some numbers are categorical (ID numbers, jersey numbers)
Explain reasoning for data type classification

exemplarProblems.problemText: Classify each of the following as categorical or numerical data: (a) Colors of cars in a parking lot (b) Heights of students in a class (c) Football jersey numbers
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Categorical - colors are labels/categories, not measurements. (b) Numerical - heights are measurements that can be compared. (c) Categorical - jersey numbers are labels to identify players, not quantities you can measure or calculate with.

exemplarProblems.problemText: A survey collects: student names, ages, and favorite subjects. Which of these are numerical data?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Only ages are numerical data (can be measured and compared). Names and favorite subjects are categorical data (labels/categories).

trickyCategorical: Phone numbers (look like numbers but are labels)
Student ID numbers (labels to identify students)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to classify 2-3 data types
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - this is conceptual understanding
Include at least one 'tricky' example with numbers that are actually categorical
Mix obvious examples (colors, heights) with borderline cases (jersey numbers, phone numbers)
Students must explain WHY each is categorical or numerical
Emphasize: numerical = can measure or count; categorical = labels or categories
Test understanding by asking which data can be used in calculations (only numerical)

stat-node-2.title: Discrete vs Continuous Numerical Data
learningFocus: Identify discrete data (specific values, usually whole numbers)
Identify continuous data (any value in a range)
Understand why the distinction matters for choosing diagrams

exemplarProblems.problemText: Classify as discrete or continuous: (a) Number of students in each class (b) Heights of students (c) Number of text messages sent per day
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Discrete - can only be whole numbers (0, 1, 2, 3...), cannot have 25.5 students. (b) Continuous - height can be any value (156.2 cm, 156.25 cm, etc.). (c) Discrete - can only be whole numbers (0, 1, 2, 3...), cannot send 5.5 messages.

continuousExamples: Time taken (can be any value: 12.34 seconds)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question classifying 2-3 numerical data types
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Students must identify whether each is discrete or continuous
Key distinction: discrete = specific values only (often whole numbers), continuous = any value in range
Use mix of obvious (counting items = discrete) and less obvious (time = continuous, shoe size = discrete)
Students should explain WHY: 'Cannot have fractional value' OR 'Can take any value'
Connect to real-world: You can't have 2.5 siblings, but you can be 156.7 cm tall

stat-node-3.title: Matching Data Types to Diagram Types
learningFocus: Categorical data → bar chart, pie chart, or pictogram
Numerical data → dot diagram, histogram, or stem-and-leaf
Justify diagram choice based on data type

exemplarProblems.problemText: A survey collects students' favorite fruits (apple, banana, orange, mango). Which type of diagram is most appropriate: (a) Histogram (b) Bar chart (c) Stem-and-leaf diagram? Explain your choice.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (b) Bar chart is most appropriate. The data is categorical (fruit types are categories, not numbers). Bar charts are used for categorical data. Histograms and stem-and-leaf diagrams are for numerical data only.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Data shows the masses (in kg) of 25 students. Suggest TWO appropriate statistical diagrams for this data.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Possible diagrams: dot diagram, histogram, or stem-and-leaf diagram. All three are appropriate because mass is numerical data. (Bar chart and pie chart would be WRONG because they are for categorical data only.)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about choosing appropriate diagram
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - this is about decision-making
Provide clear data type (categorical OR numerical)
Students must identify appropriate diagram type(s)
Key rule: Categorical → bar chart/pie chart, Numerical → dot diagram/histogram/stem-and-leaf
Students should explain WHY their choice is appropriate
Can ask for multiple valid options or ask to eliminate inappropriate options
Emphasize that histograms are NEVER for categorical data (common error)

stat-node-4.title: Considering Data Size and Purpose
learningFocus: Small datasets (< 30) → dot diagram or stem-and-leaf
Large datasets (100+) → grouped histogram
Purpose: preserve values → stem-and-leaf; show distribution → histogram

exemplarProblems.problemText: You have travel times (in minutes) for 15 employees. Would a dot diagram or a grouped histogram be more appropriate? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: A dot diagram would be more appropriate. With only 15 values (small dataset), a dot diagram can show every individual value clearly. A grouped histogram is designed for large datasets (typically 50+ values) and would be unnecessary for just 15 data points.

exemplarProblems.problemText: A researcher has heights of 200 students. They need to find the exact median height. Should they use a stem-and-leaf diagram or a grouped histogram? Why?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: A grouped histogram would be more practical. With 200 values, a stem-and-leaf diagram would be extremely long and difficult to read. However, note that grouped histograms lose exact values, making it impossible to find the precise median. If exact values are critical, the researcher might need to use the raw data or a computer.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about appropriate diagram for given data size
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide dataset size and ask for most appropriate diagram
Key guidelines: Small (< 30) → dot diagram/stem-and-leaf, Large (100+) → grouped histogram
Can add purpose constraint: need exact values → stem-and-leaf, show pattern only → histogram
Students should explain trade-offs: dot diagram shows all values but impractical for large n
Common error: suggesting grouped histogram for 15 values (unnecessarily groups data)

stat-node-5.title: Features and Purpose of Dot Diagrams
learningFocus: Each dot represents one data value
Dots stack vertically for repeated values
Number line must have equal intervals and include ALL values in range
Best for small datasets (10-30 values)

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a dot diagram showing travel times from 18 to 25 minutes, must the number line include 19 minutes even if no one has that travel time? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Yes, the number line must include ALL values from 18 to 25, including 19, even if the frequency for 19 is zero. This ensures equal intervals and prevents misinterpretation of the data. The number line should NOT have gaps.

exemplarProblems.problemText: A dot diagram shows exam scores. There are 4 dots above the value 85. What does this tell you?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Four students scored exactly 85 marks on the exam. Each dot represents one student (one data value), and the dots are stacked vertically when multiple students get the same score.

keyFeatures: Horizontal number line with equal intervals
Must include ALL values from minimum to maximum (no gaps)
Height of stack = frequency of that value

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about dot diagram features or interpretation
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for conceptual questions
Focus on KEY CONCEPTS: each dot = one value, dots stack vertically, no gaps in number line
Common misconceptions to test: 'Can we skip values with frequency 0?' (NO!)
Test understanding of stacking: 'What does stack height mean?' (frequency)
Emphasize equal intervals requirement
Connect to real contexts to make it concrete

stat-node-6.title: When to Use Dot Diagrams
learningFocus: Advantages: shows every individual value, easy to construct, reveals mode quickly
Limitations: impractical for large datasets, inefficient for many different values

exemplarProblems.problemText: State TWO advantages and ONE disadvantage of using a dot diagram to represent numerical data.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Advantages: (1) Shows every individual data value clearly (2) Easy and quick to construct from raw data (3) Mode is immediately visible as the tallest stack. Disadvantage: Not suitable for large datasets (e.g., 100+ values) because diagram becomes too crowded and difficult to read.

advantages: Shows every individual value (unlike histograms which group data)
Easy to construct directly from raw data
No data is lost or grouped
Simple for students to understand and draw
disadvantages: Becomes very wide if data has large range
Inefficient if many different values with low frequencies
Difficult to read if too many stacks
Not suitable for continuous data with many decimal places

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about advantages and/or disadvantages
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Ask for 2 advantages and 1 disadvantage (or vice versa)
Students should explain WHY each is an advantage/disadvantage
Key advantage: preserves all values (contrast with histograms)
Key disadvantage: limited to small datasets
Can ask comparative question: 'When is dot diagram better than histogram?'

stat-node-7.title: Constructing Dot Diagrams - Equal Intervals
learningFocus: Identify range (minimum to maximum)
Draw number line with equal intervals
Include ALL values in range on number line
Place dots directly above corresponding values

exemplarProblems.problemText: Data: 5, 7, 8, 5, 9, 7, 6, 8, 7, 5. (a) What values should appear on the number line? (b) How many dots should be stacked above the value 7?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) The number line should show all values from 5 (minimum) to 9 (maximum): 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. ALL these values must be marked even though no data value is 6. (b) Three dots above 7 because three data values equal 7.

mathTool.when: Include dotDiagram when showing completed diagram or verifying answer
mathTool.when_not: When asking student to construct from scratch (let them try first)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about constructing dot diagram from small dataset (8-12 values)
Provide raw data as comma-separated list
Ask students to: (a) identify range, (b) list number line values, (c) count dots per value
STRATEGIC mathTool: Include dotDiagram in solution/verification phase, NOT in problem
Ensure dataset has repeated values (to test stacking)
Test understanding: must include ALL values in range even if frequency = 0
Use contexts from curriculum: travel times, test scores, ages

stat-node-8.title: Constructing Complete Dot Diagrams
learningFocus: Follow complete construction process
Label axis clearly with variable name and units
Ensure equal spacing between dots vertically

exemplarProblems.problemText: The ages (in years) of 10 karaoke contestants are: 22, 25, 24, 22, 26, 25, 23, 22, 24, 25. Construct a dot diagram to represent this data.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 1. Range: 22 to 26 years. 2. Number line with values 22, 23, 24, 25, 26 (equal intervals). 3. Plot dots: 3 above 22, 1 above 23, 2 above 24, 3 above 25, 1 above 26. 4. Label x-axis: 'Age (years)'.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to construct complete dot diagram
CRITICAL: Include mathTool in answer to show correct construction
Provide dataset of 10-15 values with clear context
Students must: identify range, draw number line, plot dots, label axis
Emphasize proper labeling: 'Age (years)' not just 'Age'
Use realistic contexts from curriculum PDF
Ensure some values repeat (test stacking skill)

stat-node-9.title: Identifying Range, Mode, and Outliers
learningFocus: Calculate range = maximum - minimum
Identify mode (tallest stack = highest frequency)
Recognize outliers (values far from main cluster)

exemplarProblems.problemText: The dot diagram shows the masses (in kg) of 20 students. Find: (a) the range, (b) the mode, (c) whether there are any outliers.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Range = 36 - 28 = 8 kg (from minimum 28 kg to maximum 36 kg). (b) Mode = 32 kg (the tallest stack, appearing 5 times). (c) Yes, 28 kg is an outlier - it is significantly separated from the main cluster of data (30-36 kg).

params.highlightValue: Can highlight outlier if discussing it

CRITICAL: Include mathTool with showMode=true to visualize mode
Dataset should have clear mode (one value with highest frequency)
Optionally include outlier (value 3+ units away from main cluster)
Students must: (a) calculate range with formula, (b) identify mode by frequency, (c) recognize outliers
Range formula: maximum - minimum (not just stating min and max)
Mode = most common value (not just 'tallest stack' without value)
Outlier requires explanation: WHY is it an outlier? (separated from main group)

stat-node-10.title: Describing Distributions
learningFocus: Identify clusters (groups of values close together)
Describe symmetry or skewness
Use appropriate statistical terminology

exemplarProblems.problemText: Briefly describe the distribution shown in the dot diagram of travel times (in minutes).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: The data ranges from 18 to 30 minutes. Most values are clustered around 20-23 minutes. There is an extreme value at 30 minutes (outlier). The distribution is skewed to the right (positively skewed) due to the outlier.

distributionTypes.description: values evenly spread on both sides of center
outlier on high end, most data on low end
outlier on low end, most data on high end

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to describe distribution
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing dot diagram to describe
Students should use statistical terminology: range, cluster, outlier, symmetry, skewness
Good description includes: range, clustering patterns, any outliers, shape (symmetry/skewness)
Avoid vague descriptions: 'spread out' → specify where and how
Connect to context when possible: 'Most employees take 20-22 minutes'
Test vocabulary: symmetrical, skewed, cluster, outlier

stat-node-11.title: Using Tally Marks Correctly
learningFocus: Group tally marks in 5s with diagonal stroke
List all possible values systematically
Verify total frequency matches dataset size

exemplarProblems.problemText: Scores: 3, 5, 4, 3, 6, 5, 4, 3, 5, 7, 6, 4. Create a frequency table with tally marks.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer:
Score | Tally | Frequency
3 | ||| | 3
4 | ||| | 3
5 | ||| | 3
6 | || | 2
7 | | | 1
Total: 12 ✓ (matches dataset size)

tallyRules: Fifth mark crosses diagonally through first four
Makes counting easier and reduces errors

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question creating frequency table from raw data
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for frequency tables
Provide dataset of 12-25 values
Students must: list all values (min to max), use tally marks, count frequencies
Emphasize grouping in 5s: |||| not |||||
Include values that appear 5+ times to test tally grouping
Students should verify: sum of frequencies = total data values
Missing values (frequency = 0) should still be listed

stat-node-12.title: Organizing Frequency Tables
learningFocus: Table structure: Value | Tally | Frequency columns
Include all values from minimum to maximum
Check total frequency as verification

exemplarProblems.problemText: The number of books read by 18 students in a month: 2, 3, 5, 2, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4, 3, 5, 2, 3, 4, 5, 5, 3, 4. Construct a frequency table. Verify your total.

tableStructure.verification: Total row showing sum of frequencies

Emphasize verification step: does total match n?
Use real-world contexts: books read, goals scored, test scores

stat-node-13.title: Drawing Histograms from Frequency Tables
learningFocus: Draw and label both axes (x = values, y = frequency)
Bars must touch (no gaps) - this is the histogram convention
Bar height matches frequency from table
All bars have equal width

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Frequency table:
Score | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6
Freq  | 5 | 5 | 6 | 3 | 1

Draw a histogram to represent this data.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Histogram with: x-axis labeled 'Score' showing 2, 3, 4, 5, 6; y-axis labeled 'Frequency' from 0 to 6; bars touching with heights 5, 5, 6, 3, 1 respectively.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question drawing histogram from frequency table
CRITICAL: Include mathTool in answer showing correct histogram
Provide frequency table with 4-6 values
Students must: draw axes, label both axes, draw touching bars, match heights to frequencies
KEY FEATURE: bars MUST touch (no gaps) - this distinguishes histograms from bar charts
Equal width bars required
Use realistic contexts from curriculum

stat-node-14.title: Identifying Modal Class
learningFocus: Modal class = value with highest frequency (tallest bar)
Can be identified visually from histogram

exemplarProblems.problemText: From the histogram showing test scores, (a) identify the modal class, (b) how many students scored the modal value?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Modal class = 7 (tallest bar). (b) 8 students scored 7 marks (height of tallest bar shows frequency).

modalPatterns.structure: all bars same height - no mode

mathTool.purpose: Provide histogram for modal class identification

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question identifying modal class from histogram
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing histogram
Students must identify: (a) which value is mode, (b) its frequency
Modal class = tallest bar in histogram
Can ask follow-up: 'What percentage of students scored the modal value?'
Ensure one value has clearly highest frequency (avoid ties unless testing bimodal)

stat-node-15.title: Key Differences - Histograms vs Bar Charts
learningFocus: Data type: histogram = numerical, bar chart = categorical
Bar spacing: histogram bars touch, bar chart bars have gaps
X-axis: histogram = numerical scale, bar chart = category labels
Purpose: histogram = show distribution, bar chart = compare categories

exemplarProblems.problemText: State FOUR differences between a histogram and a bar chart.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 1. Data type: Histogram for numerical data, bar chart for categorical data. 2. Bar spacing: Histogram bars touch (no gaps), bar chart bars have gaps. 3. X-axis: Histogram has numerical scale, bar chart has category labels. 4. Purpose: Histogram shows frequency distribution, bar chart compares different categories.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Why do bars touch in a histogram but have gaps in a bar chart?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Histogram bars touch because they represent continuous numerical data where values flow from one to the next (e.g., 5 to 6 with no gap between them). Bar chart bars have gaps because they represent separate discrete categories (e.g., 'Red' and 'Blue' are completely different categories with no connection between them). The gap emphasizes they are distinct categories.

keyDifferences.barSpacing: Histogram: bars touch | Bar chart: bars have gaps
keyDifferences.xAxis: Histogram: numerical scale | Bar chart: category labels
keyDifferences.purpose: Histogram: show distribution | Bar chart: compare categories
keyDifferences.xAxisOrder: Histogram: numerical order | Bar chart: any order

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about differences (list 3-4 differences) OR explanation (why bars touch/have gaps)
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for comparison questions
Focus on the 4 main differences: data type, bar spacing, x-axis type, purpose
Most important: bars touch vs gaps (this is visual distinguishing feature)
Students must explain WHY bars touch (continuous numerical) vs gaps (discrete categories)
Can ask: 'Which diagram for heights?' (histogram) 'Which for favorite colors?' (bar chart)

stat-node-16.title: Choosing Between Histogram and Bar Chart
learningFocus: Decision rule: numerical data → histogram, categorical data → bar chart
Justify choice based on data type

exemplarProblems.problemText: For each scenario, state whether a histogram or bar chart is more appropriate: (a) Eye colors of students (brown, blue, green, hazel) (b) Heights of students (in cm) (c) Favorite subjects (Math, English, Science, History)
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Bar chart - eye color is categorical data (categories/labels, not numbers). (b) Histogram - height is numerical data (measurements). (c) Bar chart - subjects are categorical data (categories, not numbers).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 3 scenarios to classify
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide mix of categorical and numerical scenarios
Students must: identify appropriate diagram type AND justify based on data type
Decision rule: Is data numerical (measurements/counts)? → Histogram. Is data categorical (labels/categories)? → Bar chart.
Common error: using histogram for categorical data (WRONG)
Include one tricky case: jersey numbers are categorical, not numerical

stat-node-17.title: Splitting Stems and Leaves Correctly
learningFocus: Stem = leading digit(s), Leaf = trailing digit (always single digit)
For two-digit numbers: stem = tens digit, leaf = units digit
For three-digit numbers: stem = first two digits, leaf = last digit

exemplarProblems.problemText: For the values 142, 157, 164, what are the stems and leaves?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 142: stem = 14, leaf = 2. 157: stem = 15, leaf = 7. 164: stem = 16, leaf = 4. (For three-digit numbers, stem is first two digits, leaf is last digit.)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A stem-and-leaf diagram shows '14 | 2 7 9'. The key states '14 | 2 means 142 cm'. List all the data values represented by this stem.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 142 cm, 147 cm, 149 cm (three values with stem 14 and leaves 2, 7, 9)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about identifying stems and leaves
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for stem-and-leaf diagrams
Test understanding of stem/leaf split for 3-digit numbers
Students must correctly identify: stem = first 2 digits, leaf = last digit
Can provide stem-and-leaf line and ask to list all values (reverse process)
Emphasize: leaves are ALWAYS single digits (0-9)
Key notation: '14 | 2 means 142' is standard format

stat-node-18.title: Sorting Stems and Leaves
learningFocus: Stems in ascending order (top to bottom)
Leaves in ascending order (left to right) within each stem
This is CRITICAL for finding median and describing distribution

exemplarProblems.problemText:
A student creates this stem-and-leaf diagram:
14 | 7 2 5
15 | 3 8 1 6
What errors has the student made?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer:
The leaves are not sorted in ascending order. Correct version:
14 | 2 5 7 (leaves sorted left to right)
15 | 1 3 6 8 (leaves sorted left to right)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about sorting or identifying sorting errors
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Common question types: (a) identify error in unsorted diagram, (b) sort given unsorted leaves
Emphasize CRITICAL RULE: Stems ascending (top to bottom), Leaves ascending (left to right)
Why sorting matters: enables finding median by counting, shows distribution clearly
Students must produce correctly sorted diagram or identify what's wrong

stat-node-19.title: Key and Proper Formatting
learningFocus: Use vertical line separator: Stem | Leaves
Include key explaining notation (e.g., '14 | 2 means 142')
Include ALL stems in range even if no leaves

exemplarProblems.problemText: Heights (cm): 151, 152, 155, 155, 158, 159, 162, 164, 165, 166. Construct a stem-and-leaf diagram with proper formatting and key.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer:
Stem | Leaves
15 | 1 2 5 5 8 9
16 | 2 4 5 6

Key: 15 | 1 means 151 cm

Note: All stems from 15 to 16 are included.

formatting.spacing: Space between stem and separator, space between leaves

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question constructing complete stem-and-leaf diagram
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool

Test understanding: must include ALL stems in range (e.g., if data has 14 and 16, must include 15 even with no leaves)
Proper format: '15 | 1 2 5 5 8 9' (spaces between leaves)
Context with units: heights (cm), scores, masses (kg)

stat-node-20.title: When and Why to Use Split Stems
learningFocus: Use split stems when a stem has many leaves (typically 8+ leaves)
Split reveals distribution patterns more clearly
Reduces crowding and makes diagram more readable

exemplarProblems.problemText: A stem '15' has 14 leaves: 0 1 1 2 3 4 5 5 6 6 7 7 8 9 9. Why would split stems be useful here?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: With 14 leaves, the stem is very crowded and difficult to read. Split stems would separate this into two rows: 15 | 0 1 1 2 3 4 (leaves 0-4) and 15 | 5 5 6 6 7 7 8 9 9 (leaves 5-9). This makes the distribution clearer and easier to analyze.

whenToSplit: Want to show distribution shape more clearly
Many values concentrated in one stem
Pattern is hard to see in regular diagram
advantages: Less crowding makes diagram more readable

CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide scenario with crowded stem (8+ leaves)
Students should explain: (1) why split is needed (too crowded), (2) how it improves readability
Key trigger: 8+ leaves in single stem
Advantage: shows distribution pattern more clearly

stat-node-21.title: Constructing Split Stem Diagrams
learningFocus: Split each stem into TWO rows: first for leaves 0-4, second for leaves 5-9
Maintain ascending order for both stems and leaves
Key remains same but indicates split stem notation

exemplarProblems.problemText: Heights (cm): 151, 151, 152, 155, 155, 156, 157, 158, 159, 160, 161, 165, 166, 167. Construct a stem-and-leaf diagram with split stems.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer:
Stem | Leaves
15 | 1 1 2
15 | 5 5 6 7 8 9
16 | 0 1
16 | 5 6 7

Key: 15 | 1 means 151 cm

(First 15 has leaves 0-4, second 15 has leaves 5-9)

notation: Both acceptable if explained in key

stat-node-22.title: Reading Values and Finding Median
learningFocus: Retrieve all original data values from diagram
Find median by counting to middle value(s)
Advantage: exact values are preserved (unlike histograms)

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Stem-and-leaf diagram shows:
14 | 2 4 7
15 | 1 1 2 3 5 5 6
16 | 0 1 4 6 7 8

Key: 14 | 2 means 142 cm

Find (a) the total number of values, (b) the median.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Total = 3 + 7 + 6 = 16 values. (b) For 16 values (even), median is average of 8th and 9th values. Counting: 142, 144, 147 (3), 151, 151, 152, 153, 155 (8th), 155 (9th)... Median = (155 + 155) / 2 = 155 cm.

medianCases.method: average of values at positions n/2 and n/2+1

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question finding median from stem-and-leaf
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide complete stem-and-leaf diagram with 12-20 values
Students must: (1) count total values, (2) find median by counting to middle
For even n: median = average of two middle values
For odd n: median = single middle value
Key advantage: can read exact values (not grouped like histograms)
Show working: count from beginning to find 8th, 9th values

stat-node-23.title: Comparing Stem-and-Leaf with Histograms
learningFocus: Stem-and-leaf preserves exact values, histogram does not
Stem-and-leaf better for medium datasets (30-100), histogram better for large (100+)
Both show distribution shape

exemplarProblems.problemText: Compare stem-and-leaf diagrams with histograms. State ONE advantage of each.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Advantage of stem-and-leaf: Preserves exact data values - you can read every original number (e.g., can find exact median). Advantage of histogram: Better for large datasets - remains readable with 100+ values, whereas stem-and-leaf becomes extremely long.

stemAndLeafAdvantages: Preserves exact values (can retrieve all original data)
Easy to find median and quartiles (just count)
histogramAdvantages: Remains compact regardless of dataset size
Clearer visual of distribution shape for large n

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question comparing the two diagram types
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Ask for advantage(s) of each, OR when to use each
Key trade-off: stem-and-leaf keeps values but gets long; histogram groups values but stays compact
Best use: stem-and-leaf for medium datasets when exact values matter
Best use: histogram for large datasets when pattern matters more than exact values
Both show distribution shape (similarity)

stat-node-24.title: Understanding Interval Notation
learningFocus: Notation a ≤ x < b means 'a included, b excluded'
Boundary value (b) belongs to NEXT interval, not this one
Intervals must be continuous (no gaps, no overlaps)

exemplarProblems.problemText: For the interval 140 ≤ x < 150: (a) Is 140 included? (b) Is 150 included? (c) Is 149.9 included?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Yes, 140 is included (≤ means 'less than or equal to'). (b) No, 150 is NOT included (< means 'less than', not 'less than or equal to'). 150 belongs to the NEXT interval. (c) Yes, 149.9 is included because it is less than 150.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Three intervals are: 0 ≤ x < 10, 10 ≤ x < 20, 20 ≤ x < 30. Where does the value 10 belong?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 10 belongs to the SECOND interval (10 ≤ x < 20). The first interval excludes 10 (x < 10), but the second interval includes it (10 ≤ x). This ensures continuous intervals with no gaps.

boundaryTests: Where does upper boundary go? (Next interval)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question testing interval notation understanding
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Focus on boundary values: students struggle with 'which boundary is included?'
Key learning: lower boundary IN, upper boundary OUT
Test with specific values: 'Does 150 belong to 140 ≤ x < 150?' (NO)
Emphasize continuity: upper of one interval = lower of next (no gaps)
Common notation: a ≤ x < b OR [a, b) OR 'a-b' (all mean same thing)

stat-node-25.title: Determining Interval Membership and Width
learningFocus: Correctly assign values to appropriate intervals
Calculate class width = upper boundary - lower boundary
All intervals must have equal width

exemplarProblems.problemText: Class intervals: 10 ≤ x < 20, 20 ≤ x < 30, 30 ≤ x < 40. (a) Which interval contains 29? (b) What is the class width?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) 29 belongs to the interval 20 ≤ x < 30 (since 20 ≤ 29 < 30 is true). (b) Class width = 30 - 20 = 10 (or 40 - 30 = 10, or 20 - 10 = 10 - all intervals have same width).

widthCalculation.formula: Class width = Upper boundary - Lower boundary

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about interval membership and/or width
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide 3-4 intervals with equal widths
Test boundary values specifically (e.g., where does 20 go if intervals are 10-20, 20-30?)
Class width calculation: upper - lower (should be same for all intervals)
Students must explain reasoning for membership
Verify understanding: all intervals must have equal width (standard requirement)

stat-node-26.title: Calculating Appropriate Class Width
learningFocus: Aim for 5-10 intervals total
Approximate width = Range ÷ Desired number of intervals
Round to 'nice' numbers (5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100)

exemplarProblems.problemText: Data ranges from 0 to 80. Calculate an appropriate class width if you want approximately 8 intervals.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Approximate width = Range ÷ Number of intervals = 80 ÷ 8 = 10. This gives class width of 10, which is a 'nice' round number. Intervals would be: 0 ≤ x < 10, 10 ≤ x < 20, ..., 70 ≤ x < 80 (exactly 8 intervals). ✓

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question calculating appropriate class width
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide: data range (min to max) and desired number of intervals (~5-10)
Formula: Approximate width = Range ÷ Desired intervals
Then round to nearest 'nice' number: 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100
Students should verify: does this width give ~5-10 intervals?
Avoid awkward numbers like 7, 13, 23 (hard to work with)

stat-node-27.title: Problems with Poor Width Choices
learningFocus: Too small width (e.g., width=1 for range 0-100) → too many intervals, defeats grouping purpose
Too large width (e.g., width=50 for range 0-100) → too few intervals, pattern hidden
Goal: balance between detail and clarity

exemplarProblems.problemText: Data ranges from 0 to 100. Explain why a class width of 2 would be a poor choice.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: A width of 2 would create 50 intervals (100 ÷ 2 = 50). This is far too many intervals - it defeats the purpose of grouping data. The histogram would be extremely wide and the pattern would be difficult to see. Better to use width of 10 (creating 10 intervals) or 20 (creating 5 intervals).

poorChoices.problem: Too many intervals - defeats grouping purpose
Too few intervals - pattern completely hidden

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question explaining why a specific width is poor
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide obviously bad choice: too small (width=1 or 2) OR too large (width=half of range)
Students must: (1) calculate how many intervals result, (2) explain why this is problematic
Too small → 'defeats purpose of grouping, pattern hard to see'
Too large → 'hides all variation, most data in one bar'
Connect to guideline: aim for 5-10 intervals

stat-node-28.title: Creating Frequency Table with Intervals
learningFocus: Create table with class intervals as rows
Ensure all intervals have equal width and are continuous
Correctly assign each data value to its interval
Verify sum of frequencies = total number of data values

exemplarProblems.problemText: Waiting times (minutes): 5, 12, 18, 22, 8, 15, 25, 19, 11, 28, 14, 21, 7, 16, 24. Using intervals 0 ≤ x < 10, 10 ≤ x < 20, 20 ≤ x < 30, create a frequency table.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question creating grouped frequency table
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide: raw dataset (15-20 values) and specified intervals
Intervals should be given (not student's choice) with equal widths
Students must: assign each value to correct interval, use tally marks, count frequencies
Verification: sum of frequencies must equal n
Test boundary understanding: where does boundary value go?

stat-node-29.title: Drawing Grouped Histogram from Table
learningFocus: X-axis shows interval boundaries (0, 10, 20, 30...)
Bars span from lower to upper boundary of each interval
Bar height = frequency for that interval
Identify modal class (interval with highest frequency)

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Frequency table:
Time (min) | 0 ≤ x < 10 | 10 ≤ x < 20 | 20 ≤ x < 30 | 30 ≤ x < 40
Frequency | 7 | 11 | 8 | 2

Draw a histogram and identify the modal class.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Histogram with x-axis boundaries at 0, 10, 20, 30, 40 and bars with heights 7, 11, 8, 2. Modal class is 10 ≤ x < 20 (highest frequency of 11).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question drawing grouped histogram from frequency table
CRITICAL: Include mathTool in answer showing correct histogram
Provide grouped frequency table with 4-5 class intervals
Students must: draw histogram with correct boundaries, bar heights match frequencies, identify modal class
X-axis: mark boundaries (0, 10, 20, 30...), not interval notation
Modal class: interval with highest frequency (tallest bar)
Bars must touch (histogram convention)

stat-node-30.title: Same Data, Different Intervals
learningFocus: Same dataset can look very different with different class widths
Narrow intervals show more detail but may look noisy
Wide intervals smooth data but hide patterns

exemplarProblems.problemText: Data ranges from 0 to 50. Compare histograms with: (a) class width 5 (10 intervals) vs (b) class width 25 (2 intervals). Which would show distribution pattern more clearly?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Width 5 (10 intervals) would show distribution pattern more clearly because it provides good detail without being too crowded. (b) Width 25 (only 2 intervals) is too wide - it would hide all variation and most data would be in just one or two bars, making it impossible to see any pattern in the distribution.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question comparing interval choice effects
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide same data range with 2-3 different class width options
Students should identify which shows pattern best and explain why
Too narrow: defeats purpose of grouping, looks like ungrouped data
Too wide: hides all variation, most data in one bar
Just right: 5-10 intervals showing clear pattern with adequate detail

stat-node-31.title: Critical Evaluation of Histograms
learningFocus: Check if class width is reasonable
Verify all intervals have equal width
Consider if different intervals might show different pattern
Recognize potentially misleading histograms

exemplarProblems.problemText: A histogram shows test scores with intervals: 0-20, 20-30, 30-35, 35-50. Identify TWO problems with this histogram.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Problem 1: Unequal interval widths (first interval width 20, second width 10, third width 5, fourth width 15). This makes it impossible to fairly compare bar heights. Problem 2: The unequal widths could be misleading - a tall narrow bar might have fewer values than a short wide bar.

evaluationChecklist: Are all intervals equal width? (MUST be)
Is class width reasonable for data range?
Could different intervals show different pattern?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question evaluating histogram for problems
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Present histogram with obvious problem: unequal widths, too many/few intervals, unclear labels
Students must identify problem(s) and explain why problematic
Most serious: unequal widths (makes comparison invalid)
Other issues: too many/few intervals, misleading scales
Connect to honesty: histograms should represent data fairly
